subject: statistics
title: T-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, Paired
contentHtml:
T-tests are a fundamental concept in statistical hypothesis testing. They help us determine whether there's a statistically significant difference between two population means.

In this card, we'll explore the three main types of t-tests: one-sample, two-sample, and paired t-tests.
intuition: T-tests are useful when we want to compare the means of two groups, but we don't know the population standard deviation. They're a great way to determine whether our sample is representative of the larger population.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the average height of students in different schools

subject: statistics
title: T-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Paired
contentHtml:
T-tests are a fundamental tool in statistical hypothesis testing, allowing us to compare means between different groups or populations.

In this card, we'll explore the three main types of t-tests: one-sample, two-sample, and paired. We'll also discuss their applications in machine learning and artificial intelligence.
intuition: T-tests help us determine whether the difference between two means is statistically significant, which is crucial in ML/AI when evaluating model performance or comparing different algorithms.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the accuracy of different classification models
commonMistakes: Failing to check for normality assumptions

subject: statistics
title: T-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Paired
contentHtml:
A t-test is a statistical procedure used to determine whether there's a significant difference between two population means.

The most common types of t-tests are one-sample, two-sample, and paired t-tests. The choice of which test to use depends on the research design and the type of data being analyzed.
intuition: The t-test is a powerful tool for comparing means, but it's only as good as the assumptions you make about your data. Make sure to check those assumptions before interpreting your results!
realWorldApplications: Comparing the average height of two different populations
Evaluating the effectiveness of a new treatment
commonMistakes: Failing to check for normality or equal variances
